Pretty much feature parity with Windows. Does video calls and desktop sharing. Works flawlessly and flatpak makes is easy to install.
summary: Great way to use Slack natively on Linux

description:
You get the same electron application that is available on other platforms. Bonus is that flatpak makes the installation convenient and sandboxed.

+5
It's great that we can install slack without needing to worry what platform we're on.
summary: It's Slack but less of a pain to install

description: It's great to have a sandboxed Slack integration and regardless the platform you are on.
Slack for Fedora on RPMFusion was falling behind a few versions (FC21) until it became incompatible with FC29. Flatpak saves the day! The app is great too.
The application itself has some performance issues. The flatpak works flawlessly however.
I think I'm going to try connecting by IRC. This thing is hell on my laptop's battery life.
summary: Slack itself is fine, but the app eats all your CPU and RAM

description: works great on pop!_os 19.04

The same Slack web app you’ve grown to know (maybe not love…), but in desktop app form. It’s an Electron app which means the performance and desktop integration aren’t quite what they could be, but it’s basically the same experience you’d get on a Mac or on Windows.

description: Every time I focus the slack window, it opens a new browser tab to sign me in again (despite being signed in, in the app). It is impossible to interact with the app controls in any way.
This version is much slower than just opening Slack in the browser, I have no idea why.

Hi everyone! I noticed that the Linux version of this program was having issues signing in. I reached out to Slack support and they were able to help me fix this. So here is how you do that: First, just try isoloating the account from your broswer by using icognito mode.

If that doesnt work to get you signed in, here is what worked for me:

1. Open the Slack app.
2. Switch to the browser, access https://my.slack.com/ssb/signin_redirect/fallback and click "Copy sign-In Key".
3.Switch back to the Slack app.

I hope this helped! The program runs perfectly for me now on Garuda Linux.
summary: Fix for the sign in bug:

description: Unable to browse and upload files from locations other than places that are allowed to be mounted. (Documents, Pictures etc.,)

Mostly works great, it's only the missing features when compared to Mac/Win versions:

- no draw on screen while sharing desktop in a call (X11)
- no desktop sharing (Wayland)
- no Gnome headerbar (like all electron apps :( )
- drag & drop functionality limited
summary: It's OK, but missing crucial collaboration features

Slows down my computer.

Using it on Ubuntu since 18.04 until currently 21.04, always had issues. Random hangs, "magenta screen of death" during calls, inability to draw, high memory usage... and now with Wayland you need a special flag to allow for full screen sharing:
`--enable-features=WebRTCPipeWireCapturer` 

This is a productivity, work related tool, it needs to work *flawlessly* on GNU/Linux.

It's the Electron version of Slack; nothing more or less. Works as expected on elemenetary OS, Fedora, and Endless OS. Sign-in can be a little wonky depending on your default browser, and there is some occasional performance weirdness, but overall it's what I'd expect the Slack app to be on any desktop OS.
